prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Pendency of motions in transferee court

para.paratext: The Panel may consider the pendency of motions in selecting a transferee district. The pendency of motions is a well recognized factor considered by the Panel in determining whether to order transfer[1] and in determining the timing of its transfer order.[2] Because of the Panel's preference not to preempt the consideration of important motions by a district court, the pendency of motions in one of multiple potential transferee courts may affect the Panel's evaluation of the best transferee district.
In one case the Panel expressly considered this factor, stating:

Furthermore, on principles of comity, we are reluctant to transfer any action that has an important motion under submission with a court. Since movant has a motion for a preliminary injunction sub judice in the Texas action, our selection of the Eastern District of Texas as the transferee district for this litigation allows the Texas court to rule on this motion and at the same time permits the parties to gain the benefits from coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[3]

This factor is unlikely to dictate the selection process-the Panel is not apt to transfer based solely on this factor. It may be an important factor, however, in situations where more than one logical transferee district exists.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See, e.g., In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Grain Shipments, 305 F. Supp. 3 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
See In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054, 1056 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (citation omitted).
